title: Dimitrov saves MP, survives Cerundolo after nearly 3 hours
description: Grigor Dimitrov saved a match point to survive Francisco Cerundolo on Wednesday at the Miami Open presented by Itau, where the Bulgarian claimed a gritty 150th match win at ATP Masters 1000 level and advanced to the semi-finals. Gasping for air at times in the latter stages of the match, last yearâ€™s finalist Dimitrov found enough energy to fight off Cerundolo 6-7(6), 6-4, 7-6(3) after two hours, 48 minutes. But that did not discourage Dimitrov from moving forward, instead only fuelling his determination. He took a more aggressive baseline position in the second set and converted all eight of his net points. Playing with great variety by mixing backhand slices with his trademark one-hander, Dimitrov began to dictate rallies. He did not drop a point behind in his first serve (11/11) in the second set, according to Infosys ATP Stats. Trailing 0-3 in the decider, Dimitrov mounted another comeback to become the fifth man to reach multiple Miami semi-finals after turning 30 (Andre Agassi, Jimmy Connors, Roger Federer, John Isner). html:
Miami

Dimitrov saves MP, survives Cerundolo after nearly 3 hours

Bulgarian next faces Djokovic or Korda

March 27, 2025

Peter Staples/ATP Tour

Grigor Dimitrov is aiming to go one step further than last year's runner-up finish in Miami. By ATP Staff

Grigor Dimitrov saved a match point to survive Francisco Cerundolo on Wednesday at the Miami Open presented by Itau, where the Bulgarian claimed a gritty 150th match win at ATP Masters 1000 level and advanced to the semi-finals.

Gasping for air at times in the latter stages of the match, last yearâ€™s finalist Dimitrov found enough energy to fight off Cerundolo 6-7(6), 6-4, 7-6(3) after two hours, 48 minutes. Cerundolo will rue his missed backhand return while holding match point at 6-5 in the decider.

â€” ATP Tour (@atptour) March 27, 2025

Dimitrov had his own missed opportunities in the beginning stages, letting slip seven set points in the opener, one of which he missed by dumping a routine backhand volley in the net. But that did not discourage Dimitrov from moving forward, instead only fuelling his determination. He took a more aggressive baseline position in the second set and converted all eight of his net points.

Playing with great variety by mixing backhand slices with his trademark one-hander, Dimitrov began to dictate rallies. He did not drop a point behind in his first serve (11/11) in the second set, according to Infosys ATP Stats.

Trailing 0-3 in the decider, Dimitrov mounted another comeback to become the fifth man to reach multiple Miami semi-finals after turning 30 (Andre Agassi, Jimmy Connors, Roger Federer, John Isner). He improved to 12-1 in deciding-set matches at the ATP Masters 1000 event in south Florida.

Up next for the 14th seed will be six-time champion Novak Djokovic or American Sebastian Korda.

Having arrived in Miami defending his finalist showing from last year, Dimitrovâ€™s run to the last four has him No. 18 the PIF ATP Live Rankings.
